channel.title: Baghdad calls for apology and $1b from the United States
channel.description:
(Reuters) - Iraq's capital wants the United States to apologize and pay $1 billion for the damage done to the city not by bombs but by blast walls and Humvees since the U.S.-led invasion that toppled Saddam Hussein. The city's government issued its demands in a statement on Wednesday that said Baghdad's infrastructure and aesthetics have been seriously damaged by the American military. "The U.S. forces changed this beautiful city to a camp in an ugly and destructive way, which reflected deliberate ignorance and carelessness about the simplest forms of public taste," the statement said. "Due to the huge damage, leading to a loss the Baghdad municipality cannot afford...we demand the American side apologize to Baghdad's people and pay back these expenses." The statement made no mention of damage caused by bombing. Baghdad's neighborhoods have been sealed off by miles of concrete blast walls, transforming the city into a tangled maze that contributes to massive traffic jams. Despite a sharp reduction in overall violence in recent years only 5 percent of the walls have been removed, officials said. The heavy blast walls have damaged sewer and water systems, pavement and parks, said Hakeem Abdul Zahra, the city spokesman. U.S. military Humvees, driven on street medians and through gardens, have also caused major damage, he said. "The city of Baghdad feels these violations, which have taken place for years, have caused economic and moral damage," he said. U.S. troops pulled out of Iraq's cities in June 2009 before formally ending combat operations last August. Around 50,000 remain in Iraq but they are scheduled to withdraw by year end. Baghdad is badly in need of a facelift. Electricity and trash collection are sporadic, streets are potholed and sewage treatment plants and pipes have not been renovated for years. Iraq has seen growing protests in recent weeks over poor government services. Zahra said the city's statement issued on Wednesday would be the start of its measures to get the United States to pay for damages but he did not say what other steps might be taken.

Oddly enough, I dont consider the UK and Australia from being that far from the US, thats not who i was aiming at. I had just got done reading about Britain and the US being the main two coalition forces that felt an invasion was necessary due to the threat of wmds.

 Judging by your response it seems like you view the WMD's as the [i]only[/i] cause of the invasion, which it isnt. It played a big role, but it wasnt the only reason. The UK was with us during [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulf_War]Operation Desert Storm[/url], when Saddam invaded Kuwait, so this very much explains why Britain backed our decision to invade Iraq. Many people forgot about this past after Saddam was out of power, and [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Execution_of_Saddam_Hussein]sentenced to death by his own people[/url]. I personally think we all should have left after this, but how would it look if we all invaded and destroyed the place just to get Saddam out of power, and then left it like that? Staying there proved to have consequences, but leaving could have had greater consequences when the factions all struggled for power while the country had very weak defense, which may have resulted in [i]complete[/i] neglect for civilians.

As to why I think they actually invaded the country? I know I said I couldn’t believe two countries with such military intelligence could have such a firm belief that there are WMDs capable of threatening the security of the US, UK or any of their allies, only to find out they were wrong. But maybe they did have the evidence or intelligence that they did have them, but it seems like it was greatly exaggerated to the public to justify the war.

 Contrary to popular belief, we were never worried about the WMD's threatening the homeland, more so the fact that if Saddam actually used them it could have started another gulf war, which is the last thing we need. Id like to bring up Adolf Hitler in this part of the debate. When Hitler invaded Poland not many countries took action because they figured "Alright, we'll let him have it." But country after country invaded, no one other than the countries' own resistance took action. Next thing you know we had another World War. Had Saddam marched back into Kuwait more forcefully and used his [url=http://www.cfr.org/publication/7703/iraq.html]chemical and biological weapons[/url], a second Gulf War would have been certain. As many may know, or not, most of the [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oil_reserves]worlds oil supply comes from wells in the middle east[/url]. Saddam's aim in the [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Invasion_of_Kuwait]invasion of Kuwait[/url] was to gain control of the oil wells/fields in that region after he accused (and quickly) attacked Kuwait for [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slant_drilling]slant drilling[/url]. After Desert Storm, Saddam [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kuwaiti_oil_fires]ordered his military to set fire to all the oil wells in Kuwait as they were leaving the country[/url]. Even with the wells just being set on fire, this resulted in an effect of oil prices worldwide. Imagine if they were destroyed.

Id also like to add in that the UN inspectors did find varying evidence during the search, but most was dismissed as not credible: http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/gunning/etc/arsenal.html

That is a massive mistake. I know you’ve linked to findings of ‘WMDs’, but none that were of a threat to anyone outside of that country. I think if the war hadn’t turned out to be such a total buttfuck with little to no positive effect so far, people wouldn’t have been so annoyed by it, but the clear mistakes made leave people annoyed at not only the waste of money it had been, but the loss of soliders by the coalition fores and the mess they’ve left the country in.

 As ive stated above, the WMD's were not a threat to anyone in the US or UK, but easily could have been used on neighboring countries, like Iran, when [url=http://www.rense.com/general29/wesold.htm]we sold Saddam chemical and biological weapons[/url] during the [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kuwaiti_oil_fires]Iran-Iraq war[/url]. This was a very smart idea at the time, it was like killing two birds with one stone. Iraq was in a war against Iran, and we didn't want Iran attacking Israel. Saddam kept Iran busy, so we showed support for him. During this time [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Israel_relations]Iran and Israel were not very fond of each other[/url]. And during this past decade Iran has shown more and more hostility towards Israel as it has [url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2009/12/16/iran-test-fires-longest-range-missile/]test fired long range missiles capable of hitting Israel[/url]. This is the most recent of these conflicts:

[quote]Iran’s foreign minister, Manouchehr Mottaki declared that Israel was not capable of an attack and still recovering from the 2006 war in Lebanon.[44] The Iranian Chief of the Revolutionary Guards, Mohammad Ali Jafari said Israel was within the reach of Iranian missiles and Iran would close the Strait of Hormuz, cutting off two-fifths of the global oil supply.[44] Iran has the capability to close the Strait of Hormuz or impede traffic for a month or more, and any U.S. attempts to reopen it could escalate the conflict. [55]

According to Mohammad Ali Jafari “If Israel military agresses against sovereignty and independence of the Islamic Republic of Iran, the country will use its right, established under international law which inevocably establishes the right to defend its sovereignty by all lawful means available to it. Moreover, if such aggression is penetrated, the United Nations will be obliged to repulse such an aggression towards its sovereign member”[52].

On 7 February 2010, Iran’s supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said the destruction of Israel was assured. According to the Teheran Times, Khamenei told Palestinian Islamic Jihad leader Ramadan Abdullah Shallah, “Israel is going downhill toward decline and fall and God willing its obliteration is certain”. Khamenei went on to call Israel “a symbol of atrocity, viciousness, and ugliness,” and said the West’s “support for the Zionist regime is ineffective.”[56]

Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s chief of staff, Esfandiar Rahim Mashaei, said that if Israel attacked Iran it would be destroyed within a week.[57][/quote]

Israel has also acknowledged the situation and power of Iran

In November 2003 a Scottish newspaper claimed that Israel “warned that it is prepared to take unilateral military action against Iran if the international community fails to stop any development of nuclear weapons at the country’s atomic energy facilities”.[37] It cited Israeli defence minister Shaul Mofaz stating, “under no circumstances would Israel be able to tolerate nuclear weapons in Iranian possession”. In December 2005, a British newspaper claimed that the Israeli military had been ordered by then Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon to plan for possible strikes on uranium enrichment sites in Iran in March 2006, based on Israeli intelligence estimates that Iran would be able to build nuclear weapons in two to four years.

As you can see, they do not like each other (obviously). To add onto my first reply about Saddam and the possibility of starting a second gulf war, this Iran and Israel conflict wasn’t as intense during the first Gulf War. Had a second one started, Iran could possibly take its chance to finally attack Israel and escalate the would-be conflict in the middle east.

I know, it wasn’t great before, Saddam needed taking out of power, and that could have been done, the US and its allies could have helped with that, it didn’t justify the total fuckover. Finally, I know you like to shrug off any positives the US, UK and allies would gain from this war, but you cannot deny them, it will happen eventually.

 Two of the main reasons we invaded Iraq were due to Saddams rule, and the threat of WMD's. The other reason required an invasion due to our other target - Al Qaeda. Because of the Al Qaeda presence in Iraq (now mostly in Afghanistan) an invasion was necessary to try to remove Al Qaeda forces from Iraq. Another player in this ballgame was the suspected linking between [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saddam_Hussein_and_al-Qaeda_link_allegations]Saddam and Al Qaeda[/url], in that he may have been funding the organizations.

Powell pointed out that Saddam had already supported Islamic Jihad, a radical Islamist group and that there was no reason for him not to support al-Qaeda. Powell discussed concerns that Saddam may provide al-Qaeda with chemical or biological weapons.

You go into a country, take out leadership, rebuild government, stabilise economy - now you have an ally in which you can trade with and can help, with of course big benefits to that country too, I won’t discount that, exploit the country’s natural resources.

 Ill assume you're mostly referring to oil. [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Iraq]The main income of Iraq comes from oil[/url]. With an income from a resource like that, the country could have easily bettered itself - had Saddam not kept most of the money for himself. After the fall of Saddam, the economy of Iraq quickly recovered.

The economic sanctions were fully lifted in 24 May 2003, shortly after Saddam Hussein was overthrown. This resulted in economic growth of 53% topping the list of the world’s fastest growing economy.

Using this increase in income, the US forces would try to rebuild the country and yes, provide benefits for both sides of the spectrum, where everyone is a ‘winner’.

If they succeeded in their missions over there and shown legitimate improvement, the fact they didn’t find WMDs would likely have, not been forgotten, but not been such a big deal.

It would have lessened in threat, yes, because of the lack of need to use them for economic benefits (Like Saddam tried to gain in the invasion of Kuwait). The country would have become more and more self dependent and able to create a liable force to deal with its own problems while still having a prospering and stable economy.

Glad you actually replied.

  • The weapons which America provided the Iraqis weren’t WMDs. They provided them with helicopters and short range rockets.
  • The UN inspectors didn’t find any WMDs and neither did the Americans after the war.
  • There were no terrorists or insurgents in Iraq prior to the invasion with the exception of the Kurdish Peshmerga which was formed by the CIA.

First one was disproved above, as to the second one, biological and chemical weapons were recovered constantly throughout the war and the majority of these are said to be left over from Saddams regime stockpile.

An initial glance at the WikiLeaks war logs doesn’t reveal evidence of some massive WMD program by the Saddam Hussein regime — the Bush administration’s most (in)famous rationale for invading Iraq. But chemical weapons, especially, did not vanish from the Iraqi battlefield. Remnants of Saddam’s toxic arsenal, largely destroyed after the Gulf War, remained. Jihadists, insurgents and foreign (possibly Iranian) agitators turned to these stockpiles during the Iraq conflict — and may have brewed up their own deadly agents.

WIRED

WikiLeaks Show WMD Hunt Continued in Iraq - With Surprising Results

By late 2003, even the Bush White House’s staunchest defenders were starting to give up on the idea that there were weapons of mass destruction in Iraq. But WikiLeaks’ newly-released Iraq war documents reveal that for years afterward, U.S. troops...

As to the third one, I dont see why Saddam gassed an entire town and not just the forces ‘revolting’. The majority of the deaths from the gassing were civilians and in a case like a mass gassing i would call that complete negligence. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Halabja_poison_gas_attack. Unless you were talking about the act of genocide by Saddam in 1986.

America has been policing the middle east since the end of World War 2. The middle east is practically a mess between Iraq, Iran, Syria, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, and Israel and all their religious wars and fights for oil and land. Iran is ready to nuke Israel (Iran is in the process of making them), Israel is ready to nuke Iran (And they have them). Israel is treating this as a preemptive war, Iran IIRC blames Israel for all their problems and for some reason wants to get rid of Israel. Iraq, Iran, and Syria and Pakistan have always had conflicts.[/quote]
